result.markdown:
--- title: "UO: ggplot2 Part 2" date: "2022-02-21" categories: [R, Data Visuals] toc: true --- These are my notes from the University of Oregon's Data Service Consultants workshop on ggplot2, part 2. Cameron Mulder ran this workshop. He can be contacted via U of O's [consultation page](https://library.uoregon.edu/research-data-management/consultations). ![](ggplot2.png) ::: {.cell} ::: # `1. Set Up` For this post we used the following packages: * ggplot2: to create nice looking plots. * magrittr: to pipe `%>%`. * dplyr: to use `filter()`. * flametree: to make art. * ozmaps: to make Australian Maps. * rmapshaper: to use `ms_simplyfy` to simplify polygons. * plotly: to create interactive plots. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) library(magrittr) library(dplyr) library(flametree) library(ozmaps) library(rmapshaper) library(plotly) ``` ::: And the following data sets: * cars * [BOD](https://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-devel/library/datasets/html/BOD.html)(Biochemical Oxygen Demand) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data("cars") data ("BOD") ``` ::: # `2. ggplot2 Review` To start we made a simple point plot using the cars data set. Note: `ggplot(data= , mapping = aes())+ ()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = ggplot2::aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + ggplot2::geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: We can compare this to a simple plot in base R. Note : the `$` is how we id the specific variable we are wanting to work with. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} base::plot(mpg$displ, mpg$hwy) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # `3. Line Graph` Starting with base R: Note: `help(pressure)` is the same as `?pressure` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} base::plot(pressure$temperature, pressure$pressure, type = "l") # add points graphics::points(pressure$temperature, pressure$pressure) # add lines (and points) graphics::lines(pressure$temperature, pressure$pressure/2, col = "red") graphics::points(pressure$temperature, pressure$pressure/2, col = "red") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/line graph-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ggplot: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(pressure, ggplot2::aes(x = temperature, y = pressure)) + ggplot2::geom_line() + ggplot2::geom_point() + ggplot2::geom_line(ggplot2::aes(x = temperature, y = pressure/2), color = "red") + ggplot2::geom_point(ggplot2::aes(x = temperature, y = pressure/2), color = "red") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/line graph ggplot-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # `4. Bar Graphs` Base R: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} graphics::barplot(BOD$demand, names.arg = BOD$Time) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/bar graph base r-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} graphics::barplot(base::table(mtcars$cyl)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ggplot2: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(BOD, ggplot2::aes(x = base::factor(Time), y = demand)) + ggplot2::geom_col() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Notice that the 6 isn't there because of `factor()`. Note : geom_bar does counts, but column has the height of the bar based on the data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(mtcars, aes(x=cyl)) + ggplot2::geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/bargraph ggplot cars-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # `5. Histogram` Base R: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} graphics::hist(mtcars$mpg, breaks = 4) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ggplot2: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(mtcars, ggplot2::aes(x=mpg)) + ggplot2::geom_histogram(binwidth = 4) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # `6. Boxplot` Base R: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} base::plot(ToothGrowth$supp, ToothGrowth$len) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Base R: Formula Syntax ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} base::plot(len ~ supp, data = ToothGrowth) base::plot(len ~ supp + dose, data = ToothGrowth) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-2.png){width=672} ::: ::: ggplot2: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(ToothGrowth, ggplot2::aes(x= supp, y = len)) + ggplot2::geom_boxplot() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # `7. Time Series` ggplot2 will automatically recognize the variable as a date as long as the variable is imported as a date. To start create some dummy data: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} data <- base::data.frame( day = base::as.Date("2017-06-14")-0:364, value = stats::runif(365) ) utils::head(data) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` day value 1 2017-06-14 0.5186332 2 2017-06-13 0.7951061 3 2017-06-12 0.5442084 4 2017-06-11 0.8234817 5 2017-06-10 0.1963352 6 2017-06-09 0.9104217 ``` ::: ::: Then plot it with ggplot2: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(data, ggplot2::aes(x = day, y = value)) + ggplot2::geom_line() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Now to make a plot with the economics data set which is included in ggplot2. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(data = economics, ggplot2::aes(x = date, y = pop)) + ggplot2::geom_line() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Next create a subset of the data from 2006 and beyond: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} subset <- ggplot2::economics %>% dplyr::filter(date>base::as.Date("2006-1-1")) ``` ::: Now to create a different line graph of the subset data over time where the size of the line is based on the value of unemployment (which is the number of unemployment in thousands). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(economics, ggplot2::aes(x = date, y = pop)) + ggplot2::geom_line(ggplot2::aes(size = unemploy), color = "red") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # `8. Maps` Using `map_data()` get lat and long data for counties in Oregon: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} or_counties <- ggplot2::map_data("county", "oregon") %>% dplyr::select(lon = long, lat, group, id = subregion) utils::head(or_counties) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` lon lat group id 1 -117.2042 44.30683 1 baker 2 -117.4907 44.30683 1 baker 3 -117.4907 44.38704 1 baker 4 -117.5366 44.42142 1 baker 5 -117.5709 44.42142 1 baker 6 -117.5996 44.43861 1 baker ``` ::: ::: Using or_counties data create a ggplot2 map: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(or_counties, ggplot2::aes(lon, lat, group = group))+ ggplot2::geom_polygon(fill = "white", color = "grey") + ggplot2::coord_quickmap() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Using `ozmap_states` get the names of the different states in Australia. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} oz_stats <- ozmaps::ozmap_states oz_stats ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Simple feature collection with 9 features and 1 field Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 105.5507 ymin: -43.63203 xmax: 167.9969 ymax: -9.229287 Geodetic CRS: GDA94 # A tibble: 9 × 2 NAME geometry * 1 New South Wales (((150.7016 -35.12286, 150.6611 -35.11782, 150.6… 2 Victoria (((146.6196 -38.70196, 146.6721 -38.70259, 146.6… 3 Queensland (((148.8473 -20.3457, 148.8722 -20.37575, 148.85… 4 South Australia (((137.3481 -34.48242, 137.3749 -34.46885, 137.3… 5 Western Australia (((126.3868 -14.01168, 126.3625 -13.98264, 126.3… 6 Tasmania (((147.8397 -40.29844, 147.8902 -40.30258, 147.8… 7 Northern Territory (((136.3669 -13.84237, 136.3339 -13.83922, 136.3… 8 Australian Capital Territory (((149.2317 -35.222, 149.2346 -35.24047, 149.271… 9 Other Territories (((167.9333 -29.05421, 167.9188 -29.0344, 167.93… ``` ::: ::: Then create a ggplot2 map of Australia: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot(oz_stats)+ ggplot2::geom_sf() + ggplot2::coord_sf() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Next we remove the "Other territories", and create a multi-polygon data set of Australian Bureau of Statistics. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} oz_stats <- ozmaps::ozmap_states %>% dplyr::filter(NAME != "Other Territories") oz_votes <- rmapshaper::ms_simplify(ozmaps::abs_ced) ``` ::: Then create another map of Australian territories: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot2::ggplot()+ ggplot2::geom_sf(data = oz_stats, mapping = ggplot2::aes(fill = NAME)) + ggplot2::geom_sf(data = oz_votes, fill = NA) + ggplot2::coord_sf() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: # `9. Plotly` An interactive graph of the iris data: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} fig <- plotly::plot_ly(data = iris, x = ~Sepal.Length, y = ~Petal.Length) fig ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: An interactive plot of the cars data set: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpg %>% plotly::plot_ly(x = ~displ, y = ~mpg, color = ~class) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: Note: you can double click on the legend to see a subset of the data. Another plot with ggplot2: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot <- ggplot2::ggplot(mpg, ggplot2::aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) + ggplot2::geom_point(mapping = aes(color = class)) + ggplot2::geom_smooth() plot ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Use `ggplotly` to make it interactive: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plotly::ggplotly(plot) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: # `10. Art` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} shades <- c("blue", "green", "red", "orange") data <- flametree::flametree_grow(time = 10, trees = 10) data %>% flametree::flametree_plot( background = "white", palette = shades, style = "nativeflora" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Package by Danielle Navarro. Check out her [art](https://art.djnavarro.net/).
